contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer uses the words "daytime" and "night" to mean he prays to God all the time. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]])
These extremes include everything in between. Alternate translation: "all the time" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]])
This refers to two extremes and means for all time. Alternate translation: "for all eternity" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]])
This phrase refers to the entire day by referring to both its beginning and end. Alternate translation: "all day long" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]])
Together the words "rich" and "poor" refer to all people, regardless of wealth. Alternate translation: "all people" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]])
The author refers to all people by referring to those who have the most and least wisdom. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]])
contextId.glQuote: Wise men die; the fool and the brute alike perish

contextId.occurrenceNote: This phrase refers to the directions east, where the sun rises, and west, where the sun sets. The writer uses these two extremes to represent everywhere on earth. Alternate translation: "everywhere on earth" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]])
contextId.glQuote: from the rising of the sun to its setting

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to men of all levels of wealth and importance. The phrases "are vanity" and "are a lie" have the same meaning. One cannot confidently trust in anyone. Alternate translation: "you cannot place your trust in men, no matter how important they are" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: men of low standing ... men of high standing are a lie

contextId.occurrenceNote: Both of these expressions are merisms and refer to the whole earth. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]])
contextId.glQuote: from sea to sea, and from the River to the ends of the earth

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer uses these words with opposite meanings to say that he cries out continually. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]])
The writer uses the words "north" and "south" together to mean that God created everything everywhere. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]])
These two phrases taken together refer to all possible times of night and day. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]])
These two phrases taken together refer to all possible times of night and day. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]])
This means that Yahweh's love continues forever. Alternate translation: "will continue forever" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]])
This means creatures of all sizes. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]])

This refers to two extremes and means for all time. See how you translated this in [Psalms 41:13](../041/013.md). Alternate translation: "for all eternity" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]])

Here the four directions are given to emphasize that he gather them from everywhere. Alternate translation: "from every direction" or "from every part of the world" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]])
contextId.glQuote: from the east ... and from the south

contextId.occurrenceNote: This phrase refers to the directions east, where the sun rises, and west, where the sun sets. The writer uses these two extremes to represent everywhere on earth. See how you translated this in [Psalms 50:1](../050/001.md). Alternate translation: "Everywhere on earth" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]])
contextId.glQuote: From the rising of the sun to its setting

contextId.occurrenceNote: "both small and great." Possible meanings are that this refers 1) to social status or 2) to age. In either case, the two extremes represent every person, regardless of age or social status. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]])

The contrasting terms "day" and "night" refer to those extremes and everything in between. Alternate translation: "God protects you from the elements at all times" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]])
contextId.glQuote: The sun will not harm you by day, nor the moon by night

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here, this phrase means "always." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]])
The phrase "heaven and earth" here represents all things. Alternate translation: "everything in heaven and earth" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]])
The psalmist uses these two actions to represent everything he does. Alternate translation: "everything I do" or "everything about me" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]])
contextId.glQuote: when I sit down and when I get up

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words "heaven" and "earth" represent everything that exists in the physical universe. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]])
The words "wild" and "tame" are opposites. Together they encompass all animals. Alternate translation: "all animals" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]])
The writer uses two merisms, one related to gender and one related to age, to represent every person. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]])
contextId.glQuote: young men and young women, elderly and children
